Cell. 2002; 13: 542-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar Open table in a new tab Protein Purification, Protein-Lipid Overlays, and Surface Plasmon Resonance Experiments—Recombinant GST fusion proteins were purified from E. coli. Briefly, fresh BL21DE3 transformants expressing GST, GST-Cla4PH, or GST-PLCδPH were grown overnight in a 2-ml LB-amp culture. One liter of LB-amp was inoculated and grown to an A600 of 0.6–0.8. Isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactoside was added to a final concentration of 0.2 mm to induce fusion protein expression, and the cultures were grown for 16 h at 25 °C. Cells were collected by centrifugation for 20 min at 1000 × g. Pellets were suspended in 25 ml of ice-cold Buffer A (50 mm Hepes, 0.5 mm EDTA, 300 mm NaCl, 1 mm dithiothreitol, pH 7.4) containing protease inhibitors. Cells were lysed by one round of freeze-thawing in the presence of 2 mm dithiothreitol, treated with lysozyme and Triton X-100 (0.5% final concentration), and incubated on ice for 2–4 h. Samples were clarified by centrifugation at 20,000 × g for 1 h at 4 °C. The resultant supernatant fraction was filtered before overnight incubation with 2 ml of glutathione-Sepharose 4B (Amersham Biosciences). The supernatant/glutathione-agarose mixture was poured into a column and washed with Buffer B (20 mm Hepes, 25 mm NaCl, 2% glycerol, 1 mm dithiothreitol, pH 7.4) with and then without Triton X-100. GST fusion proteins were eluted with buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, 150 mm NaCl, 25 mm glutathione, pH 8), and fractions were collected. Relevant fractions were identified by measuring protein concentrations, which were pooled and dialyzed overnight. GST fusion proteins were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at –80 °C in glycerol-containing buffer. Protein-lipid overlays were performed as described previously (42Dowler S. Currie R.A. Downes C.P. Alessi D.R. Biochem. J. 1999; 342: 7-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). Briefly, nitrocellulose membranes spotted with 100 pmol of various purified phospholipids (Echelon, Inc.) were incubated in blocking buffer (TBST (50 mm Tris HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 0.1% Tween containing 3% fatty acid-free bovine serum albumin (Sigma)) for at least 1 h prior to addition of GST fusion proteins. Recombinant GST, GST-Cla4PH, or GST-PLCδPH (0.5 μg/ml) was added to the blocking buffer, and blots were incubated overnight at 4 °C. Blots were washed with TBST (6 times over 30 min) and incubated with rabbit polyclonal antibody to GST for 2 h at room temperature (1:10,000 dilution in TBST). After blots were washed, they were incubated with goat anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (1:2000 dilution in TBST; ICN Biomedicals, Inc.). Protein binding was detected by enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham Biosciences). Surface plasmon resonance experiments were performed as described (32Yu J.W. Lemmon M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 44179-44184Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). Dioleoylphosphatidylcholine vesicles lacking or containing 3% (mol/mol) PI3P, PI4P, PI4,5P2, or PI3,5P2 were prepared and immobilized onto an L1 sensor chip using a Biacore X instrument. For purified GST-PH fusion proteins tested, protein concentration was determined by comparison with bovine serum albumin standards on SDS-PAGE, and for the binding analysis of purified untagged PH domains, protein concentration was determined by absorbance at 280 nm. Microscopy—To localize GFP-tagged proteins expressed in yeast, we transformed relevant yeast strains with plasmids expressing GFP-tagged proteins of interest or fused GFP to the protein of interest expressed from the chromosome. Plasmid-containing cells were grown overnight in 2 ml of selective media, diluted the next day, and grown to early log phase. For experiments using temperature-sensitive PI kinase mutants, a portion of the culture was shifted from permissive (26 °C) to non-permissive (37 °C) temperature. After incubation for 1–2 h, cells were collected by brief centrifugation and visualized by fluorescence microscopy with a temperature-controlled microscope as described below. For studies involving yeast strains expressing mutant forms of the Stt4 or Mss4 PI kinases, we grew wild type and mutant strains in media containing 1 m sorbitol to provide osmotic support and prevent cell lysis as described previously (19Audhya A. Foti M. Emr S.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2000; 11: 2673-2689Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar, 43Stefan C.J. Audhya A. Emr S.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 542-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar). Fluorescence images of live cells were collected using a cooled CCD camera (DAGE) mounted on a temperature-controlled Olympus IX 70 inverted microscope equipped with a UPlanApo 100× objective. Images were acquired and analyzed with NIH Image 1.62. Immunoblotting—Yeast cell extracts were prepared by lysing cells with NaOH (44Yaffe M.P. Schatz G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 4819-4823Crossref PubMed Scopus (349) Google Scholar). Proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose. Blots were blocked, probed with a rabbit polyclonal antibody against GFP (1:2000 dilution (45Seedorf M. Damelin M. Kahana J. Taura T. Silver P.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 1547-1557Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar)) and goat anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (ICN Biomedicals, Inc.), and visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence detection (Amersham Biosciences). To determine how Cdc42 and phosphoinositide signaling in yeast is integrated into networks that co-regulate specific cell biological processes, we focused on Cla4, a PAK-related protein kinase that is a direct effector of Cdc42 (Fig. 1A). The rationale for doing so was severalfold. In contrast to other proteins such as Boi1 that bind Cdc42 by poorly understood mechanisms, Cla4 uses its conserved PBD to bind Cdc42 (46Benton B.K. Tinkelenberg A. Gonzalez I. Cross F.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 5067-5076Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). Furthermore, Cla4 probably binds Cdc42 by a mechanism highly similar to that used by mammalian PAK1 because the residues in PAK1 that bind Cdc42 are conserved in Cla4 (Fig. 1B) (47Morreale A. Venkatesan M. Mott H.R. Owen D. Nietlispach D. Lowe P.N. Laue E.D. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 384-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). Likewise, structural studies of PH domain-containing proteins have identified sequence features directly involved in binding the phosphoinositide head group (48Essen L.O. Perisic O. Cheung R. Katan M. Williams R.L. Nature. 1996; 380: 595-602Crossref PubMed Scopus (519) Google Scholar). Several of these residues are conserved in the Cla4 PH domain (Fig. 1C), although it is unknown whether the Cla4 PH domain binds phosphoinositides. Finally, phosphoinositide kinase mutants are available to determine whether Cla4 is regulated by phosphoinositide production (17Homma K. Terui S. Minemura M. Qadota H. Anraku Y. Kanaho Y. Ohya Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15779-15786Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar, 18Desrivieres S. Cooke F.T. Parker P.J. Hall M.N. J. Biol. Cell. 2002; 2: 593-605Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (216) Google Scholar, 21Walch-Solimena C. Novick P. Nat. Cell Biol. 1999; 1: 523-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar). The PH Domain of Cla4 Binds Phosphoinositides in Vitro—We determined initially whether the Cla4 PH domain binds phosphoinositides in vitro by performing protein-lipid overlay assays and surface plasmon resonance experiments. For protein-lipid overlay assays, we incubated nitrocellulose membranes containing spots of pure phosphoinositides or other lipids with purified GST fusion proteins containing the PH domain of Cla4 or the PH domain of PLCδ as a positive control. Membranes were washed and probed with an anti-GST antibody to detect binding of GST-tagged PH domains. The results indicated that the GST-Cla4 PH fusion protein binds most strongly to the monophosphorylated phosphoinositides PI3P, PI4P, and PI5P, and to PI3,5P2 (Fig. 2A). The Cla4 PH domain bound less strongly to several other lipids including PI4,5P2. At an equivalent concentration, a GST fusion containing the PLCδ PH domain bound strongly to PI4,5P2 and weakly to other lipids (Fig. 2A), confirming the specificity of this PH domain (49Lemmon M. Ferguson K. O'Brien R. Sigler P. Schlessinger J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 10472-10476Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar). GST without a PH domain did not bind (data not shown). Therefore, the PH domain of Cla4 is similar to many PH domains that bind in vitro to several phosphoinositide species (50Kavran J.M. Klein D.E. Lee A. Falasca M. Isakoff S.J. Skolnik E.Y. Lemmon M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30497-30508Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (379) Google Scholar). To complement qualitative measures of phosphoinositide-PH domain interaction determined by lipid overlay assays, we performed quantitative surface plasmon resonance (SPR) experiments to determine the affinity of the Cla4 PH domain for various phosphoinositides. These experiments used dioleoylphosphatidylcholine vesicles containing 3% (mol/mol) PI3P, PI4P, PI3,5P2, or PI4,5P2 immobilized on sensor chips. Responses of sensor chips were recorded following exposure to various concentrations of the purified His-tagged Cla4 PH domain. The resultant dose-response curves indicated that the Cla4 PH domain binds with highest affinity to PI4,5P2 (Kd = 20 μm) and PI3,5P2 (Kd = 21 μm) (Fig. 2B). By comparison, the PLCδ PH domain was found to bind PI4,5P2 with a Kd of 1.7 μm (data not shown). We also found that the Cla4 PH domain binds PI3P or PI4P with lower affinity (Kd > 100 μm; Fig. 2B). The relative affinity of the Cla4 PH domain for various phosphoinositides suggested by the results of SPR experime

Nuclear factor (NF)-kappaB p50 protein is involved in promoting survival in hippocampal neurons after trimethyltin (TMT)-injury. In the current study, hippocampal NF-kappaB activity was examined and quantitated from transgenic kappaB-lacZ reporter mice after chemical-induced injury. NF-kappaB activity was localized primarily to hippocampal neurons and significantly elevated over that in saline-treated mice between 4 and 21 days after TMT injection. Seven days after TMT injection, a timepoint of elevated NF-kappaB activity, gene expression in the hippocampus was studied by microarray analysis through comparison of expression profiles between treated nontransgenic and p50-null mice with their saline-injected controls. Seventeen genes increased in nontransgenic TMT-treated mice relative to saline-treated as well as showing no increase in p50-null mice, indicating a role for p50 in their regulation. One of these genes, the Na+, K+-ATPase-gamma subunit, was detected in brain for the first time. Several of the genes modulated by NF-kappaB are potentially related to neuroplasticity, providing additional evidence that this transcription factor is a neuroprotective signal in the hippocampus.

Interleukin-2 tyrosine kinase, Itk, is an important member of the Tec family of non-receptor tyrosine kinases that play a central role in signaling through antigen receptors such as the T-cell receptor, B-cell receptor, and Fcϵ. Selective inhibition of Itk may be an important way of modulating many diseases involving heightened or inappropriate activation of the immune system. In addition to an unliganded nonphophorylated Itk catalytic kinase domain, we determined the crystal structures of the phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated kinase domain bound to staurosporine, a potent broad-spectrum kinase inhibitor. These structures are useful for the design of novel, highly potent and selective Itk inhibitors and provide insight into the influence of inhibitor binding and phosphorylation on the conformation of Itk. Interleukin-2 tyrosine kinase, Itk, is an important member of the Tec family of non-receptor tyrosine kinases that play a central role in signaling through antigen receptors such as the T-cell receptor, B-cell receptor, and Fcϵ. Selective inhibition of Itk may be an important way of modulating many diseases involving heightened or inappropriate activation of the immune system. In addition to an unliganded nonphophorylated Itk catalytic kinase domain, we determined the crystal structures of the phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated kinase domain bound to staurosporine, a potent broad-spectrum kinase inhibitor. These structures are useful for the design of novel, highly potent and selective Itk inhibitors and provide insight into the influence of inhibitor binding and phosphorylation on the conformation of Itk. The Tec kinases are a family of five non-receptor tyrosine kinases that play a central role in signaling through antigen-receptors such as the T-cell receptor (TCR), 1The abbreviations used are: TCR, T-cell receptor; IL, interleukin; SH domain, Src homology domain; PH domain, pleckstrin homology domain; TH domain, Tec homology domain; Tec, tyrosine kinase expressed in hepatocellular carcinoma; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; MES, 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; r.m.s., root mean square. 1The abbreviations used are: TCR, T-cell receptor; IL, interleukin; SH domain, Src homology domain; PH domain, pleckstrin homology domain; TH domain, Tec homology domain; Tec, tyrosine kinase expressed in hepatocellular carcinoma; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; MES, 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; r.m.s., root mean square. B-cell receptor, and Fcϵ (1Miller A.T. Berg L.J. Curr. Opin. Immunol. 2002; 14: 331-340Google Scholar) and are essential for T-cell activation. Three members of the family, Itk, Rlk, and Tec, are activated downstream of antigen receptor engagement in T-cells and transmit signals to downstream effectors, including PLC-γ. A fourth member, Btk, appears to act independently of T-cell signaling and is essential for B-cell development and activation. Btk-deficient murine mast cells have reduced degranulation and decreased production of proinflammatory cytokines following FcϵRI cross-linking (2Kawakami Y. Kitaura J. Hata D. Yao L. Kawakami T.J. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1999; 65: 286-290Google Scholar). Btk deletion in mice has a profound effect on B-cell proliferation induced by anti-IgM and inhibits immune responses to thymus-independent type II antigens (3Ellmeier W. Jung S. Sunshine M.J. Hatam F. Xu Y. Baltimore D. Mano H. Littman D.R. J. Exp. Med. 2000; 192: 1611-1623Google Scholar, 4Mukhopadhyay S. Mohanty M. Mangla A. George A. Bal V. Rath S. Ravindran B. J. Immunol. 2002; 168: 2914-2921Google Scholar). A biological role for the final member of this family, Bmx, has not been identified. Itk is a key member of this family, and a number of factors point to the importance of this kinase in immune disease. Deletion of Itk in mice results in reduced TCR-induced proliferation and secretion of the cytokines IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, and interferon-γ (5Schaeffer E.M. Debnath J. Yap G. McVicar D. Liao X.C. Littman D.R. Sher A. Varmus H.E. Lenardo M.J. Schwartzberg P.L. Science. 1999; 284: 638-641Google Scholar, 6Fowell D.J. Shinkai K. Liao X.C. Beebe A.M. Coffman R.L. Littman D.R. Locksley R.M. Immunity. 1999; 11: 399-409Google Scholar, 7Schaeffer E.M. Yap G.S. Lewis C.M. Czar M.J. McVicar D.W. Cheever A.W. Sher A. Schwartzberg P.L. Nat. Immunol. 2001; 2: 1183-1188Google Scholar). Also, the immunological symptoms of allergic asthma are attenuated in Itk-/- mice, and lung inflammation, eosinophil infiltration, and mucous production are drastically reduced in response to challenge with the allergen OVA (8Mueller C. August A. J. Immunol. 2003; 170: 5056-5063Google Scholar). Furthermore, the Itk gene is reported to be more highly expressed in peripheral blood T-cells from patients with moderate or severe atopic dermatitis than in controls or patients with mild atopic dermatitis (9Matsumoto Y. Oshida T. Obayashi I. Imai Y. Matsui K. Yoshida N.L. Nagata N. Ogawa K. Obayashi M. Kashiwabara T. Gunji S. Nagasu T. Sugita Y. Tanaka T. Tsujimoto G. Katsunuma T. Akasawa A. Saito H. Int. Arch. Allergy Immunol. 2002; 129: 327-340Google Scholar). In certain cell types, the role of Itk may be intricately linked with other members of the family. For example, in mast cells, Btk and Itk are both expressed and activated by FcϵRI cross-linking (10Kawakami Y. Yao L. Tashiro M. Gibson S. Mills G.B. Kawakami T.J. Immunology. 1995; 155: 3556-3562Google Scholar). Splenocytes from Rlk-/- mice secrete half the IL-2 produced by wild type animals in response to TCR engagement (5Schaeffer E.M. Debnath J. Yap G. McVicar D. Liao X.C. Littman D.R. Sher A. Varmus H.E. Lenardo M.J. Schwartzberg P.L. Science. 1999; 284: 638-641Google Scholar), whereas the combined deletion of Itk and Rlk in mice leads to a profound inhibition of TCR-induced responses, including proliferation and production of the cytokines IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and interferon-γ (5Schaeffer E.M. Debnath J. Yap G. McVicar D. Liao X.C. Littman D.R. Sher A. Varmus H.E. Lenardo M.J. Schwartzberg P.L. Science. 1999; 284: 638-641Google Scholar, 7Schaeffer E.M. Yap G.S. Lewis C.M. Czar M.J. McVicar D.W. Cheever A.W. Sher A. Schwartzberg P.L. Nat. Immunol. 2001; 2: 1183-1188Google Scholar). Furthermore, intracellular signaling following TCR engagement is affected in Itk/Rlk-deficient T-cells, where inositol triphosphate production, calcium mobilization, mitogen-activated protein kinase activation, and activation of the transcription factors NFAT and AP-1 are all reduced (5Schaeffer E.M. Debnath J. Yap G. McVicar D. Liao X.C. Littman D.R. Sher A. Varmus H.E. Lenardo M.J. Schwartzberg P.L. Science. 1999; 284: 638-641Google Scholar, 7Schaeffer E.M. Yap G.S. Lewis C.M. Czar M.J. McVicar D.W. Cheever A.W. Sher A. Schwartzberg P.L. Nat. Immunol. 2001; 2: 1183-1188Google Scholar). Together, these studies have defined an important role for Itk in TCR signaling leading to thymic development, cytokine gene expression, and activation-induced cell death. However, modulation of immunological disease with small molecule Itk inhibitors will require that they are both potent and selective within the Tec family and against other kinases. Thus, crystal structures of Itk provide essential information for researchers seeking to exploit the potential of Itk inhibition, and the work described herein represents a major step forward in this quest. To date, the only other member of the Tec family of tyrosine kinases for which a crystal structure of the catalytic domain is available is an inactive form of murine Btk (11Mao C. Zhou M. Uckun F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 41435-41443Google Scholar). Itk shares a similar subunit structure with the other members of the Tec family, being composed of SH2, SH3, and catalytic kinase domains. The SH2 and SH3 domains may have important modular functions in the targeting signaling molecules to specific locations and regulation of intramolecular interactions (12Pawson T. Nash P. Science. 2003; 300: 445-452Google Scholar, 13Xu W. Harrison S.C. Eck M.J. Nature. 1997; 385: 595-602Google Scholar). However, in contrast to the homologous Src and Abl/Arg protein tyrosine kinase families, which contain N-terminal lipid modulation signals, Itk contains a pleckstrin homology (PH) domain that acts as a membrane-targeting unit (14Scharenberg A.M. El-Hillal O. Fruman D.A. Beitz L.O. Li Z. Lin S. Gout I. Cantley L.C. Rawlings D.J. Kinet J.P. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 1961-1972Google Scholar). Additionally, the region between this PH and the SH3 domain is unique to Tec kinases and has been called the Tec homology (TH) region (15Vihinen M. Nilsson L. Smith C.I. FEBS Lett. 1994; 350: 263-265Google Scholar). Deletion of the SH3 and TH regions has been shown to affect the catalytic efficiency of the kinase but not the ATP binding affinity (16Hawkins J. Marcy A. Protein Expression Purif. 2001; 22: 211-219Google Scholar) (See Fig. 1). Here we report the crystal structures of the unphosphorylated and the phosphorylated kinase domains of Itk in complex with staurosporine at high resolution. For comparison, we have also determined the crystal structure of the unliganded and unphosphorylated form of the Itk kinase domain. Expression, Purification, and Enzymatic Characterization—A truncated version of the Itk kinase domain (residues 357–620) was inserted into the bacterial/baculoviral expression vector pBEV10, 2Chambers, S. P., Austen, D. A., Fulghum, J. R., and Kim, W. (2004) Protein Expression Purif., in press. incorporating an N-terminal hexahistidine purification tag and thrombin cleavage site. The enzyme was overexpressed in baculovirus expression system using Hi5 insect cells. Itk was purified using nickel/nitrilotriacetic acid-agarose metal affinity chromatography (Novagen), and the hexahistidine tag was then removed by overnight incubation at 4 °C with 22 units of mg-1 thrombin (Sigma). Subsequent purification by size exclusion on a Superdex 200(26/60) column (Amersham Biosciences) yielded a homogeneous, unphosphorylated sample suitable for crystallization. Activation of this purified Itk protein was performed by incubating a small protein sample with 1:100 (w/w) Lck:Itk overnight at 4 °C in the presence of 10 mm MgCl2 and 5 mm ATP. Separation of the phosphorylated Itk protein from unphosphorylated protein was achieved by a ResourceQ column purification step. Phosphorylation of Itk by Lck was confirmed by Western blotting using a monoclonal phosphotyrosine antibody from Cell Signaling (P.N.9411). The phosphorylated and unphosphorylated Itk protein samples were desalted on a Hiload desalting (16/60) column (Amersham Biosciences) equilibrated with 25 mm Tris, pH 8.6, containing 50 mm NaCl and 2 mm dithiothreitol at 4 °C and concentrated to 10 mg/ml for crystallization. Dynamic light scattering (data not shown) was used to determine the most suitable protein buffer for crystallographic studies. Radiometric kinase assays were performed for the Itk enzyme used in crystallography (residues 357–620) and an Itk enzyme containing the catalytic kinase domain and the TH and SH2 domains (residues 113–620). The assay buffer consisted of 10 mm MOPS (pH 8), 10 mm MgCl2, 0.1% bovine serum albumin, 0.01% Tween 20, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. Assays were carried out in a total volume of 100 μl at 25 °C in the presence of 60 nm Itk, 5 μm SAM68 peptide substrate (Src-associated in mitosis 68-kDa protein (31Di Fruscio M. Chen T. Richard S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 2710-2715Google Scholar), residues 332–443), 2 μl of staurosporine Me2SO solution, and 150 μm [γ-33P]ATP (200 μCi of [33P]ATP/μmol ATP (Amersham Biosciences)). Kinetic parameters were calculated from nonlinear regression. ATP Km determinations were performed in the above conditions over the [γ-33P]ATP concentration range of 0 to 250 μm. Mass Spectrometry and Phosphorylation Site Identification—All proteins used in crystallization studies were characterized using mass spectrometry. Protein mass determination was performed on a Micromass Quattro II mass spectrometer with an HP1100 HPLC system. 5 μg of protein was loaded onto a Phenomenex C4 reversed phase column and eluted into the mass spectrometer in 0.1% formic acid and acetonitrile. The system was standardized against horse heart myoglobin, and mass determination was performed using MassLynx software. The mass of the basal Itk protein was determined to be 30,598.5 ± 3.4 daltons, compared with an expected mass of 30,598.1 daltons for the thrombin cleaved enzyme. The mass of the Lck-activated Itk protein was determined to be 30,678.3 ± 2.2 daltons, indicating the presence of one phosphorylation. The unphosphorylated and phosphorylated enzymes were then digested with modified trypsin (Promega) and subjected to liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry on an Applied Biosystems QSTAR quadropole time-of-flight mass spectrometer coupled to an LC Packings (Dionex) HPLC system using the Analyst and MASCOT (Matrix Science) software. The resulting tandem mass spectrometry data showed good coverage of the protein with the peptide FVLDDQYTSSTGTK phosphorylated on the tyrosine in the Lck-activated Itk protein only. This identified phosphopeptide corresponds to residues 506–519 in Itk. Manual interpretation of the data as well as automatic determination using the MASCOT software confirms the presence of the phosphate on tyrosine 512. Crystallization—Crystals of phosphorylated Itk (residues 357–620) were grown in the presence of 0.5 mm staurosporine by hanging-drop vapor diffusion from a solution of 0.8 m ammonium sulfate, 0.1 m sodium citrate, pH 5.7, 0.2 m magnesium acetate, and 10 mm dithiothreitol. Plate-like crystals formed after about 5 days at 20 °C, growing to a maximum size of 150 × 150 × 5 μm in 2 weeks. Crystals of the unphosphorylated Itk-staurosporine complex were obtained in the same conditions and grew with the same morphology. Crystals of apounphosphosphorylated Itk (residues 357–620) were grown by hangingdrop vapor diffusion from a solution of 6% polyethylene glycol 3350, 0.2 m ammonium acetate, and 0.1 m MES, pH 5.7. For data collection at 100 K, crystals were equilibriated for 20 s in a solution of mother liquor containing 30% glycerol as cryoprotectant. Data Collection and Refinement—Data for the frozen Itk-staurosporine crystals were collected at beamline 14.1 (Synchrotron Radiation Source, CCLRC Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, UK) using an ADSC Q4 CCD detector and nitrogen cryostream. Data for the frozen apo-Itk crystals were collected “in-house” using CuKα radiation. All data were reduced using MOSFLM (32Leslie A.G. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1999; 55: 1696-1702Google Scholar) and CCP4 (33Collaborative Computational Project No. 4Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. replacement (34Navaza J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1994; 50: 157-163Google Scholar) using a simplified homology model based on the known crystal structure of Btk and data between 15 and 3.5Å. Two molecules/asymmetric unit were identified with an R-factor of 47.0% (correlation coefficient of 27.1). The unphosphorylated staurosporine complex and the apo, unphosphorylated structures were subsequently solved using the phosphorylated form as starting model. All initial structures were subjected to multiple rounds of molecular dynamics refinement in CNX (Accelrys Inc., San Diego, CA ©2000) and manual rebuilding in Turbo-Frodo (35Roussel A. Cambillau C. Silicon Graphics Geometry Partners Directory.Vol. 81. Silicon Graphics, Mountain View, CA1991: 86Google Scholar) and Quanta (Molecular Simulations, Inc., San Diego, CA, ©1998, 2000). During structure refinement noncrystallographic symmetry restraints for positional parameters and B-factors were applied with weights of 400 and 5 σ (B) in crystallography NMR software, respectively. The bound staurosporine molecule could be seen clearly in the active sites (see Fig. 2). Coordinates—Refined x-ray coordinates for the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated staurosporine complex structures have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank data base with accession codes 1ITK and 2ITK. The unphosphorylated apo-Itk structure has also been deposited with accession code 3ITK. Overall Structure of Itk Kinase Domain—The phosphorylated and unphosphorylated Itk kinase domains (residues 357–620) crystallized with staurosporine in similar conditions and formed crystals of similar morphology. The unliganded Itk enzyme crystallizes in a different space group. The structure of the phosphorylated form was solved by molecular replacement using a homology model based on the known crystal structure of Btk (Protein Data Bank entry 1K2P). The unphosphorylated staurosporine complex and apo forms were subsequently solved using the phosphorylated form as the starting model. In the three crystal structures, the electron density for residues 502–521, which corresponds to the activation loop and incorporates the activating trans-phosphorylation site Tyr512, is absent because of disorder. The crystal structures of Itk have a fold typical of protein kinases (17Hanks S.K. Quinn A.M. Hunter T. Science. 1988; 241: 42-52Google Scholar, 18Sicheri F. Kuriyan J. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1997; 7: 777-785Google Scholar), comprising a small N-terminal lobe (residues 357–437) connected to the large C-terminal lobe (residues 438–620) via a flexible hinge region (see Fig. 1). This hinge region is located in the cleft between the two lobes and forms part of the catalytic active site in which staurosporine binds. The N-terminal lobe is a five-stranded anti-parallel β-sheet with a single α-helix connecting two of the strands. The C-terminal lobe is mainly α-helical and contains the substrate-binding site located in a groove on its surface. The overall topology of the Itk kinase domain is most similar to Src family kinases such as Lck (13Xu W. Harrison S.C. Eck M.J. Nature. 1997; 385: 595-602Google Scholar, 19Yamaguchi H. Hendrickson W.A. Nature. 1996; 384: 484-489Google Scholar) and distinct from serine/threonine kinases such as Cdk2 (20Brown N.R. Noble M.E. Lawrie A.M. Morris M.C. Tunnah P. Divita G. Johnson L.N. Endicott J.A. J..Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 8746-8756Google Scholar) and Aurora-2 (21Cheetham G.M. Knegtel R.M. Coll J.T. Renwick S.B. Swenson L. Weber P. Lippke J.A. Austen D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 42419-42422Google Scholar). For residues located in the catalytic kinase domain of phosphorylated Itk, the r.m.s. deviations for all main chain atoms with Src and Lck are 2.23 and 1.88 Å as compared with 8.97 and 6.68 Å for Cdk2 and Aurora-2, respectively The phosphorylated and unphosphorylated inhibitor-bound Itk structures can be readily superimposed with an r.m.s. deviation for 245 C-α atoms of 0.37 Å. In both structures, the αC-helix is completely ordered, placing the catalytically important residues Glu406, Lys391, and Asp500 in an orientation that resembles the active form of a protein kinase (by reference to the structure of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (22Narayana N. Cox S. Shaltiel S. Taylor S.S. Xuong N. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 4438-4448Google Scholar)). The unliganded and unphosphorylated structure of murine Btk (11Mao C. Zhou M. Uckun F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 41435-41443Google Scholar) resembles the liganded structure of Itk in both the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated forms (r.m.s. deviation for 243 C-α atoms of 1.4 and 1.5 Å, respectively). However, there are a number of important differences in the N-terminal kinase lobe of Itk, which are confined to two regions, the αC-helix and its preceding loop (residues 393–413) and also the glycine-rich loop (residues 362–378). These two loop regions are adjacent to each other in the Itk structure and determine the overall size and shape of the ATP-binding pocket. Most importantly, the glycine-rich loop in Itk assumes a more open and extended conformation, reminiscent of an active kinase. In contrast, this loop is collapsed into the active site of Btk in what appears to be an inactive conformation (Fig. 2). Also, in Itk, the αC-helix and preceding loop have rotated around residues Lys391 and Met410 by an angle of 12° vertically and 11° horizontally relative to the corresponding region in the Btk structure. In this way, the C-helix and residue Glu406 in Itk are moved closer to the bound inhibitor and the other catalytically important residues, Lys391 and Asp500. This active conformation of the αC-helix and adjacent loop region in Itk is stabilized by significant hydrophobic interactions established at three positions in the active site. First, residue Met398 stacks against the aromatic ring of Phe374, constraining the arrangement of the αC-helix and glycine-rich loop. Phe403 and Met410 make further hydrophobic interactions, packing closely with Ile431, Leu433, and Phe435. Together, Met398, Phe403, Ala407, Met410, and Met411 (from the αC-helix), Phe374 (from the Gly-rich loop), and Val424, Leu433, and Lys391 define an extensive hydrophobic pocket lying adjacent to the Itk active site. The size and shape of this pocket are different in the Src Tyr kinase family as well as the Ser/Thr kinases such as Cdk2. Although residues Met398, Phe403, and Met410 are conserved in Itk and Btk, Phe435 is unique to Itk (see Table II). This residue is therefore identified as a gatekeeper or blocker of this hydrophobic pocket and might thereby play a critical role in a quest for selective inhibitors of Itk over Btk as well as other kinase families (Figs. 2 and 3).Table IISequence comparison of active site residues in the TEC family kinases For comparison, residues in and around the bound ATP-binding site of Itk have been grouped according to how they interact with ATP, by references to other protein kinase structures. Therefore, residues that are essential in creating the binding pocket for adenosine, the ribose moiety, and the first and second (TP2) phosphate groups of ATP are differentiated. Similarly, residues that create the p-fluorophenyl binding pocket, first observed in the MAP kinase family (30Wilson K.P. McCaffrey P.G. Hsiao K. Pazhanisamy S. Galullo V. Bemis G.W. Fitzgibbon M.J. Caron P.R. Murcko M.A. Su M.S. Chem. Biol. 1997; 4: 423-431Google Scholar), are indicated by FP. The interaction of these residues with staurosporine can be seen in Figs. 2 and 3. The conserved kinase catalytic residue is indicated in blue, an unusual cysteine residue in magenta, and the specificity-determining gatekeeper residue, Phe435, in red. Targeting new interactions between an inhibitor and residue Cys442 may be a way to improve selectivity for the TEC-family kinases over homologous kinases such as Lck and Src, which have serine residues at this position. Residue numbering corresponds to Itk. Open table in a new tab The ability of protein kinases to alternate between catalytically active and inactive states in response to specific signals underlies their use as molecular switches. The N- and C-terminal lobes have been seen to alter their relative orientations in a number of different kinase structures, with a closed conformation being associated with the active form of the kinase as it correctly positions the γ-phosphate group of ATP with respect to the substrate. Inactive forms of protein kinases have been observed in various open configurations in which the two lobes of the catalytic domain are further apart. Itk is phosphorylated at the membrane on residue Tyr512 in the activation loop segment of the catalytic subunit by Src family kinases (23Mahajan S. Fargnoli J. Burkhardt A.L. Kut S.A. Saouaf S.J. Bolen J.B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 5304-5311Google Scholar, 24Backesjo C.M. Vargas L. Superti-Furga G. Smith C.I. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 299: 510-515Google Scholar). The unphosphorylated and phosphorylated-staurosporine structures of Itk superimpose closely on the unphosphorylated apo structure (r.m.s of 1.1 Å for 245 Cα atoms) with no reorientation of the N- and C-terminal lobes, indicating that large scale conformational changes within the kinase domain are not induced by phosphorylation on Tyr512. Interactions in the ATP-binding Site of Itk—The active site of Itk is bounded by the glycine-rich loop, which contains the consensus kinase sequence Gly-X-Gly-X-X-Gly (residues 370–375), and the hinge region (residues 435–442). Staurosporine binds to the Itk kinase domain at the interface of the N- and C-terminal lobes via hydrophobic interactions with Ile369, Val377, and Ala389 (N-terminal lobe), Phe435 and Tyr437 (hinge region), and Leu489 and Cys442 (C-terminal lobe), all of which line the active site. Upon ligand binding, the gatekeeper residue, Phe435, makes a beneficial edge-face interaction with the conjugated ring system of staurosporine. In addition, the lactam group mimics the interactions of the adenine base in ATP with the hinge region of the protein backbone, where two conserved hydrogen bonds are formed between the lactam-nitrogen N-19 in staurosporine and the carboxyl group of Glu436 and the lactam-oxygen O-30 with the backbone amine group of Met438 (see Fig. 2). An additional hydrogen bond is mimicked in the staurosporine sugar moiety, where the methylamino group contacts the backbone carbonyl of Arg486. Unlike the PKA (cAMP-dependent protein kinase)-staurosporine complex (25Prade L. Engh R.A. Girod A. Kinzel V. Huber R. Bossemeyer D. Structure. 1997; 5: 1627-1637Google Scholar), there is no hydrogen bond between this methylamino group and the Oδ2 of Glu127 (PKA numbering) because this is a cysteine (Cys442) in ITK. The extent of these interactions is reflected in the potency of staurosporine for the isolated kinase domain (Ki ≤ 10 nm) (see “Materials and Methods”). In the unliganded Itk structure, the αC-helix and residue Phe435 are more disordered than in the complexed structures (as judged by refined atomic B-factors and electron density maps). Thus the formation of the staurosporine complex is sufficient to complete a transition to an ordered conformation of the kinase domain. Furthermore, the similar active conformations of the phosphorylated and unphosphorylated staurosporine complexes appears to be independent of crystal packing artifacts as the uncomplexed Itk enzyme crystallizes in a different space group. Staurosporine-induced conformational changes of protein kinases, including considerable induced-fit rearrangement with the inhibitor and opening or closing of the active site have been observed previously (25Prade L. Engh R.A. Girod A. Kinzel V. Huber R. Bossemeyer D. Structure. 1997; 5: 1627-1637Google Scholar). Activating Role of Tyr512 Phosphorylation in Itk—For several protein kinases including Irk, calmodulin-dependent kinase, protein kinase II, myosin light chain kinase, and protein kinase C, a pseudo-substrate sequence within the activation loop has been observed to block access to the substrate-binding pocket of the catalytic cleft. Phosphorylation of the activation loop is thus required to remove this pseudo-substrate sequence and promote the active kinase conformation. In Itk, the ATP-binding site is not occluded by the activation loop, and therefore phosphorylation of residue Tyr512 appears to have no role to play in a self-inhibitory mechanism. In reporting the inactive crystal structure of murine Btk, the authors speculated upon an activation mechanism that is triggered upon phosphorylation of the equivalent activation loop tyrosine, Tyr551. This proposal suggested that in the unphosphorylated state of Btk, Arg544 binds to Glu445. Upon activation by a Src family kinase this interaction is released, so that Arg544 now binds to the phosphorylated Tyr551 and brings about a large conformational change involving the αC-helix. This conformational movement enables Glu445 to bind to the catalytic Lys430 in a movement that primes the nucleotide-binding pocket for ATP binding. Hence, phosphorylation on Tyr551 would have the effect of both preventing the engagement of Glu445 in the catalytic center and stabilizing a new conformation of the αC-helix. This mechanism is similar to that proposed by Yamaguchi and Hendrickson (19Yamaguchi H. Hendrickson W.A. Nature. 1996; 384: 484-489Google Scholar) for the activation of Lck (Protein Data Bank code 3lck) where phosphorylation of Tyr394 causes a switch in the orientation of Arg363, resulting in a restructuring of the activation segment, which then no longer impedes the inward movement of the C-helix. In contrast with these activation mechanisms, our results demonstrate that no similar conformational changes are triggered in Itk upon inhibitor binding to the ATP-binding pocket of the unphosphorylated apo-enzyme. Moreover, no subsequent conformational movements occur upon phosphorylation of the ligand bound form. This suggests that Tyr512 is not essential in the preparatory activation steps, because the architecture of the ATP- and substrate-binding sites are already compatible with ATP (or inhibitor) binding. This surprising result brings into question the activating role of phosphorylation of Tyr512 in Itk. Like all Tec family members, Itk possesses both SH2 and SH3 domains. In addition, Itk has a PH and a TH domain within which are a GTPase-activating protein homology region and a proline-rich region. It is possible that one or more of these might have an influence in the formation of the substrate binding site and reorganization around the phospho-tyrosine site. To explore the role of these noncatalytic domains we have determined that the Kcat of Itk is reduced by 26-fold upon deletion of the SH2, SH3, and TH domains, whereas the affinity (Km) for ATP and Ki for staurosporine remain relatively unchanged (see “Materials and Methods”). This is consistent with complete activation of Itk in primary T-cells requiring autophosphorylation at residue Tyr180 subsequent to transphosphorylation in the activation loop (26Wilcox H.M. Berg L.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 37112-37121Google Scholar). These data and our structures therefore suggest an intricate regulation mechanism in Itk involving the SH2, SH3, and TH domains, a mechanism that is distinct from the proposed activation of Btk and the simple activation mechanism of many serine-threonine kinases. Possible insight into this auto-activation mechanism might be provided by comparison with Src, another phosphotyrosine kinase. The structure of c-Src, comprising the SH3, SH2, catalytic domain, and regulatory C-terminal tail, has been determined in the inactive form. The SH2 and SH3 domains are located on the distal surface of the catalytic domain, leaving both nucleotide- and peptide-binding sites unimpeded. Their role appears to be to influence the location of the αC-helix via an interaction with the SH2-linker region where Gln251 and Gln253 interact with Gln324 (in the loop following αC-helix) and Arg318 (in the αC-helix), respectively. The two residues in the SH2 linker are not conserved in Itk, and in sequence alignments map to a valine and alanine, respectively, that can no longer interact with the corresponding residues, Gln420 (in the loop after αC-helix) and Ser414 (in the αC-helix). In the absence of these important interactions between the SH2 linker and the catalytic domain, it is likely that the linker follows a different conformation, with the possible consequence that the SH domains are not assembled in the same manner as Src (27Brazin K.N. Fulton D.B. Andreotti A.H. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 302: 607-623Google Scholar, 28Pursglove S.E. Mulhern T.D. Mackay J.P. Hinds M.G. Booker G.W. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 755-762Google Scholar). This hypothesis is confirmed in solution studies on Btk where the full-length enzyme adopts a linear arrangement (29Marquez J.A. Smith C.I. Petoukhov M.V. Lo Surdo P. Mattsson P.T. Knekt M. Westlund A. Scheffzek K. Saraste M. Svergun D.I. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 4616-4624Google Scholar). In a linear arrangement, the full-length enzyme might dimerize, and Tyr512 might then play a role in the autophosphorylation of the SH3 domain of the dimeric partner. Implications for Structure-based Drug Design—The work described in this article provides a strong basis for the design and development of novel immunomodulatory therapies. In determining the crystal structures of the phosphorylated and unphosphorylated Itk kinase domains in ligand-bound and apo forms, we have shown that phosphorylation of Tyr512 does not induce order in the activation loop or promote rearrangement of protein side chains in the ATP-binding site. This includes the catalytically essential residues, which appear to have active conformations in both structures. This leads us to postulate that an Itk inhibitor will bind with similar affinity to the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated kinase domains. This surprising result, which provides the first structural evidence for dual inhibition of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated Itk, has not been observed for any other kinase. Furthermore, our results highlight the significance of residue Phe435 as gatekeeper to an extensive hydrophobic pocket in the ATP-binding site and its key role in the design of selective inhibitors. This is important, as selective inhibition of Itk may be a way of modulating a number of specific immune diseases. 3J. Das, J. Wityak, C. Liu, R. V. Moquin, J. A. Furch, J. Lin, S. H. Spergel, A. M. Doweyko, A. Kamath, H. Zang, K. D. O'Day, B. Penhallow, C.-Y. Hung, S. Kanner, T.-A. Lin, J. H. Dodd, and J. C. Barrish, Medicinal Chemistry Poster MEDI 63, presented at the 226th American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting, New York (September 7–11, 2003) and Poster MEDI 257, presented at the 225th ACS National Meeting, New Orleans (March 23–27, 2003). Alternatively, an inhibitor of the other TEC family members (Btk, Rlk, Tec, and Bmx) may exploit the smaller threonine residue at this position, either via a hydrogen-bonding interaction or by accessing the hydrophobic pocket. A broad-spectrum inhibitor of the entire Tec family could be achieved using small lipophilic groups positioned close to residue Phe435. Such inhibitors may have a general role in noncytotoxic immunosuppression. We thank Julian Golec for valuable comments and critical reading of the manuscript. We thank John Pollard for help in setting up enzyme assays, Ronald Knegtel for construction of an Itk homology model, and Peter Charlton, Ronald Knegtel, and Juan-Miguel Jimenez for helpful discussions.

The thiazide-sensitive Na+:Cl- cotransporter is the major salt transport pathway in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, and a role of this cotransporter in blood pressure homeostasis has been defined by physiological studies on pressure natriuresis and by its involvement in monogenic diseases that feature arterial hypotension or hypertension. Data base analysis revealed that 135 single nucleotide polymorphisms along the human SLC12A3 gene that encodes the Na+:Cl- cotransporter have been reported. Eight are located within the coding region, and one results in a single amino acid change; the residue glycine at the position 264 is changed to alanine (G264A). This residue is located within the fourth transmembrane domain of the predicted structure. Because Gly-264 is a highly conserved residue, we studied the functional properties of this polymorphism by using in vitro mutagenesis and the heterologous expression system in Xenopus laevis oocytes. G264A resulted in a significant and reproducible reduction (∼50%) in 22Na+ uptake when compared with the wild type cotransporter. The affinity for extracellular Cl- and for thiazide diuretics was increased in G264A. Western blot analysis showed similar immunoreactive bands between the wild type and the G264A cotransporters, and confocal images of oocytes injected with enhanced green fluorescent protein-tagged wild type and G264A cotransporter showed no differences in the protein surface expression level. These observations suggest that the G264A polymorphism is associated with reduction in the substrate translocation rate of the cotransporter, due to a decrease in the intrinsic activity. Our study also reveals a role of the transmembrane segment 4 in defining the affinity for extracellular Cl- and thiazide diuretics. The thiazide-sensitive Na+:Cl- cotransporter is the major salt transport pathway in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, and a role of this cotransporter in blood pressure homeostasis has been defined by physiological studies on pressure natriuresis and by its involvement in monogenic diseases that feature arterial hypotension or hypertension. Data base analysis revealed that 135 single nucleotide polymorphisms along the human SLC12A3 gene that encodes the Na+:Cl- cotransporter have been reported. Eight are located within the coding region, and one results in a single amino acid change; the residue glycine at the position 264 is changed to alanine (G264A). This residue is located within the fourth transmembrane domain of the predicted structure. Because Gly-264 is a highly conserved residue, we studied the functional properties of this polymorphism by using in vitro mutagenesis and the heterologous expression system in Xenopus laevis oocytes. G264A resulted in a significant and reproducible reduction (∼50%) in 22Na+ uptake when compared with the wild type cotransporter. The affinity for extracellular Cl- and for thiazide diuretics was increased in G264A. Western blot analysis showed similar immunoreactive bands between the wild type and the G264A cotransporters, and confocal images of oocytes injected with enhanced green fluorescent protein-tagged wild type and G264A cotransporter showed no differences in the protein surface expression level. These observations suggest that the G264A polymorphism is associated with reduction in the substrate translocation rate of the cotransporter, due to a decrease in the intrinsic activity. Our study also reveals a role of the transmembrane segment 4 in defining the affinity for extracellular Cl- and thiazide diuretics. Genet. 1996; 59: 1019-1026PubMed Google Scholar), an inherited disorder featuring arterial hypotension, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypocalciuria, hypomagnesemia, and renal salt wasting. TSC also serves as the target for the thiazide-type diuretics that are currently recommended as the drug of choice for treatment of hypertension (11Chobanian A.V. Bakris G.L. Black H.R. Cushman W.C. Finally, a defect in TSC regulation by the WNK1 and WNK4 kinases has been implicated in the pathogenesis of a salt-dependent form of human hypertension known as pseudohyopaldosteronism type II (12Wilson F.H. Kahle K.T. Sabath E. Lalioti M.D. Rapson A.K. Hoover R.S. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Lifton R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 680-684Crossref PubMed Scopus (356) Google Scholar, 13Yang C.L. Investig. 2003; 111: 1039-1045Crossref PubMed Scopus (397) Google Scholar), which features marked sensitivity to hydrochlorothiazide and a clinical picture that is a mirror image of Gitelman's disease (hypertension, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis) (14Mayan H. Vered I. Mouallem M. Tzadok-Witkon M. Pauzner R. Farfel Z. J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 2002; 87: 3248-3254Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). Taken together, all these observations suggest that TSC molecular variants, resulting from single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), could contribute to the normal variations in blood pressure in the population at large, to the inherited predisposition toward essential hypertension, and/or to the differential response to diuretic therapy.Despite the important role of TSC in cardiovascular physiology, pharmacology, and pathophysiology, little is currently known about the structure-function relationships in this cotransporter. By using [3H]metolazone binding to membrane preparations from rat renal cortex, Tran et al. (15Tran J.M. Farrell M.A. Fanestil D.D. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: F908-F915PubMed Google Scholar) proposed that thiazides and Cl- share the same binding site. Recent studies in which the functional properties of the cloned cotransporter were determined, however, provided evidence that metolazone competes with both Na+ and Cl- ions (16Monroy A. Plata C. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: F161-F169Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), suggesting that the thiazide-binding site may be shared by both ions and not only by Cl-, as suggested by Tran et al. (15Tran J.M. Farrell M.A. Fanestil D.D. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: F908-F915PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, nothing is known regarding domains or amino acid residues defining the TSC ion transport kinetics or thiazide affinity. So far, within the family of electroneutral cotransporters, some aspects of the structure-function relationships have been investigated only in the two isoforms of the Na+:K+:2Cl- cotransporter, BSC1/NKCC2 and BSC2/NKCC1. Results between both isoforms, however, have shown important differences suggesting that conclusions reached in one member of the family cannot be extended to the other members. Jacoby S.C. Chang J. Forbush III, B. J. Gen. Physiol. 1998; 112: 549-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar) have implicated transmembrane domains 4 and 7 in defining Cl- transport affinity, whereas recent studies (19Plata C. Meade P. Chem. 2003; 278: 5648-5654Google Scholar) in BSC1/NKCC2 clearly showed that transmembrane domain 2 contains affinity modifier residues for extracellular Cl-.In the present study we show that an SNP that changes one amino acid residue in TSC results in a dramatic decrease in TSC function, apparently secondary to a decrease in the intrinsic activity of the cotransporter, and reveals a role of transmembrane segment 4 in TSC affinity for extracellular Cl- and for thiazide diuretics.MATERIALS AND METHODSAn extensive search of genome data bases (lpgws.nci.nih.gov/cgi-bin/GeneViewer.cgi; ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/SNP) was performed to find the SNPs that have been informed within the SLC12A3 gene. The SNPs within the coding regions that were considered as potentially important were incorporated into the rat TSC cDNA by using the QuickChange site-directed mutagenesis system (Stratagene) following the manufacturer's recommendations. Automatic DNA sequencing was used to corroborate all the mutations. All primers used for mutagenesis were custom-made (Sigma).Genotyping of the G264A Polymorphism—A restriction fragment length polymorphism method was created for the G264A polymorphism to confirm it and to simplify its detection in 200 normal subjects. Total genomic DNA was extracted from whole blood according to standard procedures. PCR was conducted using 125 ng of genomic DNA using the primer pair sense 5′-AGACCGTGCGGGACCTGCTC-3′ and antisense 5′-CCTCCTCCATGGCCTCCTCACCTT-3′. PCR was conducted for 34 cycles with denaturation at 96 °C for 30 s, annealing at 60 °C for 30 s, and extension at 72 °C for 30 s, with a final extension step at 72 °C for 5 min. The G264A variant was recognized by restriction fragment length polymorphism by using Btg1 (New England Biolabs), and the restriction fragments were separated on 7.5% PAGE, and visualized under ultraviolet light after staining with ethidium bromide. The polymorphism was confirmed by automatic sequencing (AbiPrism®) in all positive cases.Assessment of the Na+:Cl-Cotransporter Function—Oocytes were harvested from anesthetized adult female Xenopus laevis frogs, defolliculated, and prepared for microinjection following our standard procedure (16Monroy A. Plata C. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: F161-F169Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 19Plata C. Meade P. Vazquez N. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 11004-11012Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). The next day mature oocytes were injected with 50 nl of water or cRNA transcribed in vitro, using the T7 RNA polymerase mMESSAGE kit (Ambion), at a concentration of 0.5 μg/μl. Oocytes were then incubated for 3 days in ND96 with sodium pyruvate and gentamicin and 1 day in Cl--free ND96 (16Monroy A. Plata C. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: F161-F169Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The function of the Na+:Cl- cotransporter was determined by assessing tracer 22Na+ uptake (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) in groups of at least 15 oocytes following our standard protocol (16Monroy A. Plata C. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: F161-F169Crossref PubMed Google Scholar): 30 min of incubation in a Cl--free ND96 medium containing 1 mm ouabain, 0.1 mm amiloride, and 0.1 mm bumetanide, followed by a 60-min uptake period in a K+-free, NaCl medium containing the same drugs plus 2 μCi of 22Na+ per ml. Gluconate was used as a Cl- substitute and N-methyl-d-glucamine as a Na+ substitute. At the end of the uptake period tracer activity was determined for each dissolved oocyte by β-scintillation counting.Western Blotting—Western blot analysis was used to compare WT with mutant protein in cRNA-injected oocytes following our standard protocol (22Meade P. Hoover R.S. Plata C. Vazquez N. Bobadilla N.A. Gamba G. Hebert S.C. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 284: F1145-F1154Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). In brief, groups of 15 oocytes injected with water or cRNA were homogenized in 2 μl/oocyte of homogenization buffer and centrifuged twice at 100 × g for 10 min at 4 °C, and the supernatant was collected. Protein extracts from oocytes (four oocytes per lane) were heated in sample buffer containing 6% SDS, 15% glycerol, 0.3% bromphenol blue, 150 mm Tris, pH 7.6, and 2% β-mercaptoethanol, resolved by Laemmli SDS-7.5% PAGE, and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. For immunodetection we used a rabbit polyclonal anti-rat TSC antibody (generously provided by Dr. Mark Knepper, National Institutes of Health), diluted 1:1000 (23Wang X.Y. Masilamani S. Nielsen J. Kwon T.H. Brooks H.L. Nielsen S. Knepper M.A. J. Clin. Investig. 2001; 108: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). The membrane was exposed to anti-TSC antibody diluted in blocking buffer (TTBS, 0.2% Tween 20) overnight at 4 °C, subsequently washed in TTBS, and incubated for 60 min at room temperature with alkaline phosphatase-conjugated secondary (anti-rabbit) antibody (Bio-Rad) diluted 1:2000 in blocking buffer and washed again. Immunoreactive species were detected using Immun-Star Chemiluminescent Protein Detection Systems (Bio-Rad).Assessment of the TSC Expression at the Oocytes Plasma Membrane—The surface expression of wild type or mutant TSC (see below) was determined by assessing the fluorescence in the Xenopus oocytes using a TSC fusion construct that we have previously validated (12Wilson F.H. Kahle K.T. Sabath E. Lalioti M.D. Rapson A.K. Hoover R.S. Hebert S.C. Gamba G. Lifton R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 680-684Crossref PubMed Scopus (356) Google Scholar, 24Hoover R.S. Poch E. Monroy A. Vazquez N. Nishio T. Gamba G. Hebert S.C. J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 2003; 14: 271-282Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). In this construct, the EGFP was fused to the amino-terminal domain of TSC. Xenopus oocytes were then microinjected with water as control or with EGFP-WT-TSC or EGFP-mutant-TSC cRNA. After 4 days of incubation, oocytes were monitored for EGFP fluorescence in the oocytes surface using a Zeiss laser-scanning confocal microscope (objective lens ×10, Nikon). Excitation and emission wavelengths used to visualize EGFP fluorescence were 488 and 515–565 nm, respectively. We have shown previously that EGFP-TSC fluorescence in the oocytes surface colocalizes with the F-404 specific plasma membrane dye and that oocytes injected with EGFP-TSC exhibit significant thiazide-sensitive 22Na+ uptake, indicating the EGFP-TSC fluorescence is located in the plasma membrane (24Hoover R.S. Poch E. Monroy A. Vazquez N. Nishio T. Gamba G. Hebert S.C. J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 2003; 14: 271-282Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). For densitometry analysis, the plasma membrane fluorescence was quantified by determining the pixel intensity around the entire oocytes circumference using SigmaScan Pro image analysis software.Statistical Analysis—Statistical significance is defined as two-tailed p < 0.05, and the results are presented as mean ± S.E. The significance of the differences between means was tested with the Student's t test.RESULTSSingle Nucleotide Polymorphisms in the SLC12A3 Gene—Up to 135 SNPs have been informed within the SLC12A3 gene. 127 SNPs are located within intronic sequences and only eight are within exonic sequences. Two SNPs result in a single amino acid change. Thus, the G264A SNP was considered as potentially important and therefore was introduced into TSC by in vitro mutagenesis.Allele Frequency of the G264A Polymorphism—A restriction fragment length polymorphism strategy was used to assess the presence of G264A SNP by PCR. The PCR product (510 bp) contained a constant Btg1 restriction site, and therefore, when digested, two bands of 461 and 49 bp, respectively, are observed in GG genotype (encoding glycine at position 264 in both alleles). In contrast, in GA genotype heterozygotes (that is one allele encoding glycine and the other encoding alanine at position 264), a new specific Btg1 restriction site was used, and then four bands of 461, 390, 71, and 49 bp were observed. To test the allele frequency of the G264A polymorphism, 200 Caucasian subjects were genotyped. The sample included 119 males and 81 females with the following characteristics (mean ± S.D.): age 52 ± 16 years, systolic blood pressure 117 ± 11 mmHg, diastolic blood pressure 69 ± 7 mmHg, and body mass index of 24 ± 4 kg/m2. None of the subjects had present or past cardiovascular conditions including hypertension, coronary heart disease, stroke, or diabetes. The frequency of the GA genotype was 2% in the sample studied. No subjects with AA phenotype were detected (that is homozygotes encoding alanine at position 264 in both alleles). Shown in Fig. 2A is a representative gel containing the Btg1-digested PCR fragment from a normal subject and one heterozygous for the GA genotype. Fig. 2, B and C, illustrates sequencing of this region in a GG and a GA phenotype (codons GGC and GCC, respectively). As shown in Fig. 3, WT or G264A cRNA injection induced a significant increase in 22Na+ uptake in X. laevis oocytes. However, the increase in G264A-injected oocytes was of a significantly lower magnitude than the increase observed in WT oocytes. Uptake in WT-injected oocytes was 3448 ± 234 pmol oocyte-1 h-1, whereas in G264A-injected oocytes was 1712 ± 366 pmol oocyte-1 h-1 (p < 0.01, n = 20). As shown in Fig. 3, the uptake was due to the TSC activity because a complete inhibition of uptake was observed in the absence of extracellular chloride or in the presence of the thiazide-type diuretic, metolazone. A reduction of a similar magnitude in the G264A activity was consistently observed in every single experiment. In order to ensure that the reduction in 22Na+ uptake was not due to differences in the amount of cRNA injected or in the transcription rate of the protein, cRNA concentration was determined by densitometry of the corresponding bands in the ethidium bromide-stained agarose gel, and the transcribed protein was assessed by Western blot analysis of the injected oocytes. The proteolytic processing of the precursor of the β-amyloid peptides (APP) is believed to be a key event in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. This processing is activated through a pathway involving the PDGF receptor, Src, and Rac1. In this paper, we demonstrate that this pathway specifically acts on APP and requires the YENPTY motif present in the APP cytosolic domain. Considering that several results indicate that the adaptor proteins interacting with this domain affect the processing of APP, we examined their possible involvement in the PDGF-induced pathway. By using an APP-Gal4 reporter system, we observed that the overexpression of Fe65 activates APP-Gal4 cleavage, whereas X11 stabilizes APP. Although mDab1 and Jip1 have no effect, Shc induces a strong activation of APP cleavage, and the contemporary exposure of cells to PDGF causes a dramatic cooperative effect. The analysis of point mutations of the APP YENPTY motif indicates that Fe65 and PDGF function through different mechanisms. In fact, Fe65 requires the integrity of APP695 Tyr682 residue, whereas PDGF effect is dependent upon the integrity of Asn684. Furthermore, the mutation of Asp664 of APP, which is the target site for the caspase-directed APP cleavage, strongly decreases the effect of Fe65. This suggests that Fe65 activates the cleavage of APP by caspases, and in fact, caspase inhibitor Z-VEVD decreases the APP cleavage induced by Fe65. On the contrary, the effects of Shc overexpression, like those of PDGF, are completely absent in the presence of compound X and require the integrity of the Asn684 residue of APP695. The involvement of Shc in the pathway regulating APP processing is confirmed by the effects of constitutively active and dominant negative mutants of Src and Rac1. The proteolytic processing of the precursor of the β-amyloid peptides (APP) is believed to be a key event in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. This processing is activated through a pathway involving the PDGF receptor, Src, and Rac1. In this paper, we demonstrate that this pathway specifically acts on APP and requires the YENPTY motif present in the APP cytosolic domain. Considering that several results indicate that the adaptor proteins interacting with this domain affect the processing of APP, we examined their possible involvement in the PDGF-induced pathway. By using an APP-Gal4 reporter system, we observed that the overexpression of Fe65 activates APP-Gal4 cleavage, whereas X11 stabilizes APP. Although mDab1 and Jip1 have no effect, Shc induces a strong activation of APP cleavage, and the contemporary exposure of cells to PDGF causes a dramatic cooperative effect. The analysis of point mutations of the APP YENPTY motif indicates that Fe65 and PDGF function through different mechanisms. In fact, Fe65 requires the integrity of APP695 Tyr682 residue, whereas PDGF effect is dependent upon the integrity of Asn684. Furthermore, the mutation of Asp664 of APP, which is the target site for the caspase-directed APP cleavage, strongly decreases the effect of Fe65. This suggests that Fe65 activates the cleavage of APP by caspases, and in fact, caspase inhibitor Z-VEVD decreases the APP cleavage induced by Fe65. On the contrary, the effects of Shc overexpression, like those of PDGF, are completely absent in the presence of compound X and require the integrity of the Asn684 residue of APP695. The involvement of Shc in the pathway regulating APP processing is confirmed by the effects of constitutively active and dominant negative mutants of Src and Rac1. Fe65 is not involved in the platelet-derived growth factor-induced processing of Alzheimer's amyloid precursor protein, which activates its caspase-directed cleavage. Vol. 279 (2004) 16161-16169Journal of Biological ChemistryVol. 279Issue 27PreviewPages 16161, 16162, and 16163: Throughout these pages, Cys83 and Cys99 should be changed to C83 and C99, since the latter are the standard designations for the intermediate products of the proteolytic cleavage of Alzheimer's β-amyloid precursor protein by α- and β-secretases, respectively. Therefore, there is no relation to the amino acid cysteine (Cys). Full-Text PDF Open Access Numerous experimental results indicate that the β-amyloid precursor protein (APP) 1The abbreviations used are: APP, amyloid precursor protein; AD, Alzheimer's disease; Aβ, beta-amyloid peptide; AICD, APP intracellular domain; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyl transferase; Z-D(or V)EVD-fmk, benzyloxycarbonyl-D(or V)EVD-fluoromethyl ketone; IC, intracellular; PTB, phosphotyrosine binding domain; PDGF, platelet derived growth factor; PDGF-R, PDGF receptor. plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). In fact, the main constituent of senile plaques, the β-amyloid peptide (Aβ), derives from the proteolytic processing of APP, and mutations of the APP gene are responsible for some rare cases of genetically inherited AD. Furthermore, presenilins are key factors of the molecular machinery catalyzing the cleavage of APP, and mutations of the two presenilin genes are responsible for most of the cases of familial AD (for reviews, see Refs. 1Selkoe D.J. Physiol. Rev. 2001; 81: 741-766Crossref PubMed Scopus (5170) Google Scholar and 2St. George-Hyslop P.H. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 2000; 924: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). It is well demonstrated that APP is a type I membrane protein that is cleaved by two different proteolytic enzymes, named α- and β-secretases. These cleavages generate soluble extracellular fragments, named α- and β-APPs, and two forms of transmembrane stubs, Cys83 and Cys99, as a consequence of the activity of α- and β-secretases, respectively. These stubs are then substrates of a third enzyme, the γ-secretase, which cleaves them within the transmembrane helix, thus generating from Cys99 the 40–42 amino acid-long peptide Aβ and from Cys83 a smaller fragment named p3. The cleavage of Cys83 and Cys99 by γ-secretase also results in the generation of a C-terminal peptide of 57 residues (APP intracellular domain, AICD) (3De Strooper B. Annaert W. J. Cell Sci. 2000; 113: 1857-1870Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Passer B. Pellegrini L. Russo C. Siegel R.M. Lenardo M.J. Schettini G. Bachmann M. Tabaton M. D'Adamio L. J. Alzheimer's Dis. 2000; 2: 289-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). APP is also a substrate of caspase activities that cleave its cytosolic domain, 31 residues upstream from the C terminus (5Weidemann A. Paliga K. Durrwang U. Reinhard F.B. Schuckert O. Evin G. Masters C.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 5823-5829Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar). Numerous results suggest that the short cytodomain of APP plays a key role in the regulation of these events. Therefore, it has been hypothesized that the cleavage of APP by α- and/or β-secretases and the resulting cleavage of Cys83 or Cys99 by γ-secretase result in the release of AICD from the membrane anchor and in its translocation into the nucleus, where, in association with other proteins, it could regulate gene transcription. The attractiveness of this hypothesis would be increased if the cleavage of APP and the resulting gene regulation could be triggered by events, such as extracellular signals, thus assigning to APP a role in signal transduction. We have demonstrated recently that APP processing is induced by activated PDGF receptor through a pathway involving the activation of Src and Rac1 (33Gianni D. Zambrano N. Bimonte M. Minopoli G. Mercken L. Talamo F. Scaloni A. Russo T. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 9290-9297Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). In this paper, we demonstrate that some partners of the APP cytodomain play a key role in the regulation of APP processing. In particular, Fe65 and Shc increase the cleavage of APP by two different mechanisms: Fe65 induces the caspase-dependent cleavage of APP, whereas Shc cooperates with PDGF in the activation of the secretase-directed processing of APP. N-terminal mutants of APP-Gal4 were generated in a Gal4 expression cassette obtained by cloning a PCR fragment of the yeast Gal4 cDNA between the sites NotI and ApaI of the pRcCMV vector (Invitrogen). The primers used to amplify Gal4 were: 5′-AAGGAAAAAAGCGGCCGCTGGTGGTGGTGGTGGTGGTAAGCTACTGTCTTCTATCGAACAAGC and 5′-CATCGGGCCCTTACTCTTTTTTTGGGTTTGGTGGGG. To ensure the proper membrane location of the deleted proteins, the coding sequence of the APP signal peptide was added to the 5′ end of the vector polylinker by cloning (in the HindIII site) a double-stranded synthetic oligonucleotide with a modified 5′ Hind III sequence (the upper strand sequence was: 5′-AGCTAACTAAGGCCATGCTGCCCGGTTTGGCACTGCTCCTGCTGGCCGCCTGGACGGCTCGGGCGCTGA). The C-terminal deletion mutants have been amplified by PCR with the common forward primer, 5′-CCCAAGCTTACTAAGGCCATGCTGCCCGGTTTGGCACTGC, and with the reverse primers DC07, 5′-AAGGAAAAAAGCGGCCGCCTTGTAGGTTGGATTTTCGTACGGC; DC14, 5′-AAGGAAAAAAGCGGCCGCGCCGTTCTGCTGCATCTTGGAC; and DC44, 5′-AAGGAAAAAAGCGGCCGCTTTCTTCTTC AGCATCACCAAGG. The point mutations were introduced in the wild-type APP-Gal4 construct through site-directed mutagenesis (Stratagene mutagenesis kit) with complementary primer pairs bearing the desired mutations. Cell Culture Conditions, Transfections, and Treatments—HEK293, HeLa, and HeLaAG cells were grown at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin (Invitrogen). Transfections were performed by calcium phosphate-DNA co-precipitation with equal amounts of plasmid DNA in 60-mm cell culture dishes. PDGF stimulation of transfected cells was started 24 h after transfection and allowed to proceed for 16–24hinthe presence of 40 ng/ml of recombinant human PDGF-BB (Sigma). Treatments of the cell cultures with the inhibitors were performed for the indicated times at the following concentrations: 10 μm PP2 (Calbiochem), 2 μm AG1296 (Calbiochem), 10 μm secretase inhibitor compound X (Calbiochem), 50 μm Z-DEVD-fmk (Alexis). Preparation of Cell Extracts, Western Blotting, Reporter Analyses, and Aβ Assay—For Western blot analyses, cells were harvested in cold PBS, resuspended in lysis buffer (40 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.2, 1% Triton X-100, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA) in the presence of a protease inhibitor mixture (complete EDTA-free, Roche Applied Science) and kept on ice for 15 min. Then the extracts were clarified by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4 °C. 20 μg of each extract were resolved on 4–12% SDS-polyacrylamide gradient gels (Invitrogen) under reducing conditions and transferred to Immobilon-P membranes (Millipore). Filters were blocked in 5% nonfat dry milk in T-PBS solution (phosphate-buffered saline and 0.05% Tween) and incubated overnight at 4 °C with appropriate dilutions of primary antibodies. The excess antibody was removed by sequential washing of the membranes in T-PBS, and then a 1:5000 dilution of the appropriate secondary antibody (conjugated horseradish peroxidase) was added to the filters for 30 min at room temperature. The excess was removed by sequential washing of the membranes in T-PBS, and the signals were detected by chemiluminescence, using the ECL system (Amersham Biosciences). The antibodies used and their dilutions were: anti-APP 6E10 (Sigma), 1:1000; anti-APP CT695 (Zymed Laboratories Inc., 1:250; anti-Fe65 (36Zambrano N. Buxbaum J.D. Minopoli G. Fiore F. De Candia P. De Renzis S. Faraonio R. Sabo S. Cheetham J. Sudol M. Russo T. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 6399-6405Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar), 1:2000; anti-caspase 3 (Upstate Biotechnology), 1:1000. Total extracts were clarified by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4 °C, and their protein concentration was determined by the Bio-Rad protein assay. Zambrano N. Hansen U. Russo T. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 35481-35488Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), using a Berthold tube luminometer.
